title: The Dow Fell 160 Points Because an Interim Trump-China Trade Deal Isn’t Doable
text:
Text size

Setback. All three major U.S. stock indexes closed Friday in the red, giving up earlier gains. President Donald Trump said there is no need for a trade deal with China before the 2020 election. Chinese officials canceled their visit to farms in Montana. Netflix stock (ticker: NFLX) plunged after the streaming giant’s CEO warned of tough competition coming from Apple (APPL) and Walt Disney (DIS) starting in November. Fitbit stock (FIT) soared on report that it’s considering a sale of the business. In today’s After the Bell, we...

September Tranquility

U.S. stocks ended Friday with losses as positive sentiment heading into the October U.S.-China trade talk turned sour again. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 159.72 points, or 0.59%, to close at 26,935.07. The S&P 500 has fallen 14.72 points, or 0.49%, to finish at 2992.07, and the Nasdaq Composite lost 65.21 points, or 0.80%, to close at 8117.67.

President Trump said at a press conference on Friday that there is no need for a trade deal with China before the 2020 election and that he is not looking for a partial deal with Beijing, but something broader. It is not enough for China to just buy more agricultural products from the U.S., said the president. There has been speculation about a potential interim deal at the face-to-face meeting between the two countries planned for next month.

Chinese officials canceled a planned visit to farms in Montana next week. It was not immediately clear if the move was in response to President Trump’s remarks, or if visits to other U.S. farm areas were also canceled.

Editor's Choice

U.S. stocks dropped on the news, but both the Dow and the S&P 500 are sitting not far below their all-time highs.

Global governments and central banks continued to come out with supportive policies in the face of a weakening economy. After the Central Bank of Brazil cut benchmark rates to a record low yesterday, People’s Bank of China lowered its new benchmark lending rate for the second month in a row on Friday, and India reduced its corporate tax rate to one of the lowest in Asia. In a blog post today, Fed St. Louis President James Bullard wrote that U.S. manufacturing “already appears in recession” as many estimates of recession probabilities have risen from low to moderate levels.

So far, September—historically known as one of the worst months for stocks—turned out to be not so bad this year. The S&P 500 is up 2.2% for the month and was relatively stable for most trading days.

“Over the past two weeks we’ve had the European Central Bank meeting, the Federal Reserve meeting, higher inflation, a historic jump in crude oil, Middle East turmoil, trouble in the repo market, and even multiple NFL quarterbacks sustaining major injuries,” wrote LPL Financial senior market strategist Ryan Detrick. “Yet, with all of those scary headlines, stocks are actually in the midst of one of the least volatile two-week stretches we’ve seen in years.”

But with the S&P 500 up near 3,000 points, the sea of tranquility might get rougher at any time, Detrick wrote on Friday. Investors should be on the lookout for the second half of September. On a historical basis, most of the weakness in September tends to come toward the end of the month. “Things have been going well for equities in the face of some worrisome headlines, but don’t get complacent, as the calendar could be one of the biggest near-term risks,” he wrote.
